dialogues.VAUGHAN:
[1]James Ballard? 
[2]Crash victim? 
[3]We'll deal with these later. 
[4]'Don't worry, that guy's gotta see us!' These were the confident last words of the brilliant young Hollywood star James Dean as he piloted his Porsche 550 Spyder race car toward a date with death on a lonely stretch of California two-lane blacktop, Route 466. 'Don't worry, that guy's gotta see us.' The year, 1955; the day, September thirtieth; the time: now. 
[5]The first star of our show is 'Little Bastard', James Dean's racing Porsche. He named it after himself, and had his racing number, 130, painted on it. 
[6]The second star is stuntman and former race driver -- Colin Seagrave, who will drive our replica of James Dean's car. 
[7]I myself shall play the role of James Dean's racing mechanic, Rolf Wütherich, sent over from the Porsche factory in Zuffenhausen, Germany. This mechanic was himself fated to die in a car crash in Germany twenty- six years later. And the third and in some ways most important party, the college student Donald Turnupseed, played by movie stuntman Brett Trask. 
[8]Turnupseed was on his way back to his home in Fresno for the weekend. James Dean was on his way to an automobile race in Salinas, a dusty town in northern California. The two would only meet for one moment, but it was a moment that would create a Hollywood legend. 
[9]You'll notice that we are not wearing helmets or safety padding of any kind, and our cars are not equipped with roll cages or seat-belts. We depend solely on the skill of our drivers for our safety, so that we can bring you the ultimate in authenticity. All right, here we go. The fatal crash of James Dean! 
[10]Rolf Wütherich was thrown from the Porsche and spent a year in the hospital recovering from his injuries. Donald Turnupseed was found wandering around in a daze, basically unhurt. James Dean died of a broken neck and became immortal. 
[11]Hit his head, I think. His balance is off. 
[12]It's not the police. It's the Department of Transport. Internal politics. It's a joke. They have no idea who we really are. 
[13]That was glib, wasn't it? 'James Dean died of a broken neck and became immortal.' But I couldn't resist. 
[14]I'd really like to work out the details of the Jayne Mansfield crash with you. We could do the decapitation -- her head embedded in the windshield -- and the little dead dog thing as well. You know, the Chihuahuas in the back seat. I've got it figured out. 
[15]Don't leave yet, Ballard. I want you to help me. 
[16]I live in my car. This is my workshop. 
[17]And this is the new project, Ballard. 
[18]It's something we're all intimately involved in: the reshaping of the human body by modern technology. 
[19]It excited her, Ballard. Your wife, Catherine. She enjoyed it. Ask her. 
[20]Get all the paper you can, Ballard. Some of the stuff they're giving away is terrific: 'Mechanisms of Occupant Ejection', 'Tolerances of the Human Face in Crash Impacts'... 
[21]I've always wanted to drive a crashed car. 
[22]No, I mean a crash with a history. Camus's Facel Vega, or Nathaniel West's station wagon, Grace Kelly's Rover 3500. Fix it just enough to get it rolling. Don't clean it, don't touch anything else. 
[23]The case could be made. 
[24]Take a look at this and tell me what you think. 
[25]It's the future, Ballard, and you're already part of it. For the first time, a benevolent psychopathology beckons towards us. For example, the car crash is a fertilizing rather than a destructive event -- a liberation of sexual energy that mediates the sexuality of those who have died with an intensity impossible in any other form. To fully understand that, and to live that... that is my project. 
[26]A crude sci-fi concept that floats on the surface and doesn't threaten anybody. I use it to test the resilience of my potential partners in psychopathology. 
[27]You drive. 
[28]Let's get rid of that. I don't want you blowing it up my urethra. 
[29]It's Seagrave. He was worried that we would never do Jayne Mansfield's crash, now that the police were cracking down. So he did it himself. 
[30]The dog -- God, the dog is brilliant, perfect. I wonder where he got it? 
[31]Come with me, James. I have to document it. 
[32]You're right, Ballard. There's an all-night car-wash in the airport service area. 
[33]I need to see you, Ballard. I need to talk to you about the project. 
[34]You're making it too clean. 
[35]This isn't a medical tattoo. This is a prophetic tattoo. Prophesy is dirty and ragged. Make it dirty and ragged. 
[36]There's no difference. James -- I want you to let her give you this one. 
[37]It should go here.
dialogues.HELEN:
[1]After this sort of thing, how do people manage to look at a car, let alone drive one? I'm trying to find Charles's car. 
[2]They said it was here. They told me this morning. 
[3]This is your car? 
[4]Were you badly hurt? I think we saw each other at the hospital. I don't want the car. In fact, I was appalled to find that I have to pay a small fee to have it scrapped. 
[5]Haven't I? To the airport, if you could. 
[6]Not yet -- though not soon enough for some people, I've already found. A death in the doctor's family makes the patients doubly uneasy. 
[7]I'll wear a bloody kimono if I want to. 
[8]I work in the immigration department there. 
[9]Do you want a cigarette? I started to smoke at the hospital. It's rather stupid of me. 
[10]It's much worse now. You noticed that, did you? The day I left the hospital I had the extraordinary feeling that all these cars were gathering for some special reason I didn't understand. There seemed to be ten times as much traffic. 
[11]You've bought yourself exactly the same car again. It's the same shape and colour. 
[12]Turn up here into the car-park. It won't be busy this time of day. 
[13]I've found that I enjoy burying myself in heavy traffic. I like to look at it. Yesterday I hired a taxi-driver to drive me around for an hour. 'Anywhere,' I said. We sat in a massive traffic jam under an off- ramp. I don't think we moved more than fifty yards. I'm thinking of taking up a new job with the Road Research Laboratory. They need a medical officer. The salary is larger -- something I've got to think about now. There's a certain moral virtue in being materialistic, I'm beginning to feel. Well, it's a new approach for me, in any case. 
[14]Yes. 
[15]That's the point. Besides, I know I can give something now that I wasn't remotely aware of before. It's not a matter of duty so much as of commitment. 
[16]The real thing is available free of charge. Besides, it's not quite legal. They can't advertise. 
[17]That's Vaughan. He talked to you at the hospital. 
[18]When I first met Vaughan, he was a specialist in international computerized traffic systems. I don't know what he is now. 
[19]I don't know. You can never be sure with Vaughan. This is his show. 
[20]I know that man, Seagrave, the stunt driver. I think he's genuinely hurt. 
[21]What's the matter with Seagrave? 
[22]They did the James Dean crash. It seemed to go perfectly. But he started to feel nauseous on the way back. I'm sure it's concussion. 
[23]Have you come? 
[24]The junior pathologist at Ashford Hospital. Then the husband of a colleague of mine, then a trainee radiologist, then the service manager at my garage. 
[25]Yes. I didn't plan it that way. 
[26]Yes. They felt like traffic accidents. 
[27]We can have a look at it again on the monitors. They're showing it in slow motion.
dialogues.RENATA:
